header_summary:
Sergio Demian Lerner and Boris Nagaev's discussion centers on advancing Bitcoin's defenses against quantum computing threats, with Lerner proposing an efficient commit/reveal scheme utilizing Taproot leaves for better transaction management without the need for additional storage, aiming to maintain Bitcoin's security integrity ([source](https://groups.google.com/g/bitcoindev/c/jr1QO95k6Uc/m/lsRHgIq_AAAJ)). Greg Sanders highlights the potential of technologies like Citrea, akin to the Lightning Network, to leverage Bitcoin's proof of publication for secure and efficient transactions, underscoring the importance of adhering to Bitcoin's core principles amidst technological advancements in finance ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/2a40a751-d0d1-4dc8-9dd5-67b7652ed8b8n@googlegroups.com)).

In the realm of privacy and security, /dev /fd0 provides a comparative analysis of CoinJoin implementations, pointing out JoinStr's superior sybil resistance over others, inviting community feedback on enhancing cryptocurrency transaction security ([source](https://uncensoredtech.substack.com/p/sybil-resistance-in-coinjoin-implementations)). Meanwhile, vostrnad discusses collaborative efforts among mining pools to support the mining of non-standard, oversized Bitcoin transactions, sparking a conversation on balancing innovation with the network's foundational principles and the potential implications for Bitcoin's decentralization and network efficiency ([source](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2025/05/27/bitlayer-joins-forces-with-antpool-f2pool-and-spiderpool-to-supercharge-bitcoin-defi)).

ClaraShk's collaboration with @deadmanoz yields a comprehensive report on the implications of quantum computing on Bitcoin, proposing strategies for adapting to and mitigating these risks to ensure the cryptocurrency's future security and viability, highlighting the importance of proactive community engagement with these challenges ([source](https://chaincode.com/bitcoin-post-quantum.pdf)). Finally, carla introduces a debate on the implementation of forwarding delays in Lightning Network transactions, exploring the balance between node incentives and operational efficiency, indicating a trend towards customizable delay settings and enhanced privacy measures without significantly complicating the network protocol ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/latency-and-privacy-in-lightning/1723/9)).

active_posts.title: Relax OP_RETURN standardness restrictions
active_posts.summary:

active_posts.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
active_posts.summary:

active_posts.title: Hashed keys are actually fully quantum secure
active_posts.summary:
- Hashed keys can be secured against quantum threats using Quantum Resistant mechanisms.
- The scheme involves QR signing and a transaction process to prove private key knowledge.
- The email supports a soft fork for implementing this quantum-resistant security strategy in Bitcoin.

active_posts.title: CTV+CSFS: Can we reach consensus on a first step towards covenants?

active_posts.title: Dust Expiry: Clean the UTXO set from spam
active_posts.summary:
- A soft-fork proposes expiring old, tiny UTXO outputs to tackle spam-induced growth.
- UTXO set doubled since 2023 due to spam, reaching 11 GB, with half considered spam.
- Community feedback is sought to refine the proposal aiming to reduce UTXO clutter.

active_posts.title: Stats on compact block reconstructions
active_posts.summary:

- Investigation reveals reconstruction time disparities, suggesting potential benefits of network-wide policy adjustments.
